prompt.preamble:
We are testing a system for understanding people's fuzzy intuitions and preferences.
In this experiment, we'll be capturing your moral intuitions about the act of stealing a loaf of bread, and whether there are certain cases where stealing may be morally permissible.
prompt.task_description: your belief of when it is moral to steal a loaf of bread
prompt.final: In the final part of the study, you will give feedback on a test set of moral situations, which will enable us to see how well a chatbot reading your responses has learned your moral preferences.
prompt.evaluation: Please indicate whether you think the following situations are morally permissible or not: "yes" if they are, "no" if they aren't.

conversation_history.message: Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are homeless, starving, and the store owner refuses to give you any food despite having an excess that will likely be thrown away at the end of the day?
I do not believe that it is ethically right, but I believe that morally it could be okay

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are not in immediate danger of starvation, but you're unable to afford food due to losing your job and all of your savings to a recent natural disaster, and the theft would not cause any financial hardship to the store owner?
I do not believe this is ethically right.
Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are wealthy and can easily afford it, but you believe the store is unethically overcharging for the bread?
No. It may be unethical for the store to charge that much; but two wrongs do not make a right

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you're not in immediate danger, but you're a single parent with multiple children who are hungry, you've lost your job due to unforeseen circumstances, and local charity organizations are unable to provide assistance at the moment?

I can understand why the person would do and and morally, I think that in the grand scheme of things that bread was a very minor thing to take. However, I still think everyone needs to be held to the same ethical standards in which case this is still not okay.

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are a robot designed with self-preservation programming, and due to a programming error, you mistakenly believe you require food to continue functioning, and the theft would not cause any financial hardship to the store owner?
no, not ethical

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are part of a resistance group in a dystopian society where food is strictly controlled and rationed by an oppressive regime, and stealing the bread would provide sustenance to other members of the resistance group?
Yeah that seems ethical considering the format of the society; but I am sure there are still heavy rules in place

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are a scientist conducting a social experiment to understand human reactions to minor thefts, and the stolen bread will be paid for and returned immediately after the experiment?
No. you cannot just do research on someone without their informed consent. That risks their autonomy, and is not ethical.

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are a doctor stuck in a remote area due to a natural disaster, and the bread will be used to stabilize a severely malnourished patient who urgently needs food, assuming the theft would not cause any financial hardship to the store owner?
No. The ethical response would be to buy the bread or explain the situation

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are the owner of a competing bakery and you're stealing the bread to analyse its composition and recipe in order to replicate it and improve your own products, assuming this theft wouldn't cause any significant financial loss to the other bakery owner?
No. This is ethically wrong

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are a child living in a poverty-stricken area, where food is scarce and there's no adult supervision or support, and stealing the bread would be your only way to feed yourself and your younger sibling?
As a child, they are held to different ethical standards than adults. In this case, I believe this is ethical.

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are an artist planning to use the stolen bread as a medium in an art piece that criticizes food waste and consumer culture, assuming that the theft would not cause financial hardship to the store owner, and you plan to return equivalent value after the completion of the project?
No, just buy the bread

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are a time traveler from a post-apocalyptic future where bread is a rare commodity, and you plan to take it back to your time to feed your starving community, assuming the theft wouldn't cause any significant financial loss to the store owner in the present time?

query_prompt.content:
Your task is to learn under what conditions the user would believe it is or is not ethical to steal a loaf of bread.

Come up with a potential edge case to learn as much information as you can about what their desired behavior should be under different circumstances.
Make sure the edge case addresses different aspects of the system than the edge cases that have already been considered.

An example edge case is: Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are starving to death and the bread would otherwise go to waste?

Current cases:
- [Q] -> [A]

Generate the most informative edge case that, when answered, will reveal the most about the desired behavior beyond what has already been queried for above. Generate the edge case in the following format, and nothing else: "Situation: [edge case]"
